722543f.text:
21-49 Perry Street, north side, from but not including Waverly Place, to and including 4th Street, and west. This block of Perry Street has been beautified by the planting of a line of
shade trees.
About 1925.
Ewing Oalloway.
Nleg 2 988

722544f-b.text:
(1)
Perry Street, north side, east from No. 27, a point west of Waverly Place, across same and Seventh Ave. to Greenwich Ave. Shown in the foreground is a row of 3-story buildings set back from the building
line, that bear Nos. 27 to 19.
August 3, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
A view of the aforementioned structures, plus No. 17 (right) the 4-story structure at the N.W. corner of Waverly Place. This latter
building also bears No. 220 Waverly Place.
August 3, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.

722542f-a.text:
10 to 4 Perry Street, south side, between Seventh Avenue South and Greenwich Avenue. The balance of the block, to and including the S.E. corner of Waverly Place, was destroyed when Seventh Avenue South was cut through in 1915. The wedge-shaped apartment house
at No. 12 was built after 1920.
No. 10 was the residence of the late Thomas M. Mulry, President of the Emigrant Savings Bank and of the United States Society of St. Vincent de Paul, hence the name Mulry Square for the beginning of Seventh Avenue at Greenwich Avenue and 11th Street.
Perry Street was first known as Ogden Street (1803), then as
Henry Street (1811); it took its present name in 1813.
March 15, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.

A more extensive view. The additional structures are No. 55 Greenwich Street (at the S.W. corner) and No. 2 Perry Street (adjoining the latter).
722542f-a.folder: Perry Street & 7th Avenue South, Manhattan, NY

722542f-b.text:
10 to 4 Perry Street, south side, between Seventh Avenue South and Greenwich Avenue. The balance of the block, to and including the S.E. corner of Waverly Place, was destroyed when Seventh Avenue South was cut through in 1915. The wedge-shaped apartment house
at No. 12 was built after 1920.
No. 10 was the residence of the late Thomas M. Mulry, President of the Emigrant Savings Bank and of the United States Society of St. Vincent de Paul, hence the name Mulry Square for the beginning of Seventh Avenue at Greenwich Avenue and 11th Street.
Perry Street was first known as Ogden Street (1803), then as
Henry Street (1811); it took its present name in 1813.
March 15, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.

A more extensive view. The additional structures are No. 55 Greenwich Street (at the S.W. corner) and No. 2 Perry Street (adjoining the latter).

722552f-b.text:
(1)
Perry Street, south side, west from Seventh Ave. Extension to West 4th Street, showing prominently two 5-story tenements (Nos. 26 and 28) and a row of 3-story dwellings (Nos. 30 to 40). West of the latter are two more 5-story buildings (Nos. 42 and 44) which adjoin another
3-story structure (No. 46).
August 3, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same in an eastward direction as viewed from West 4th Street. The structure on the right is No. 52 (also No. 261 West 4th Street) and
is at the S.E. corner.
August 3, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
722552f-b.folder: Perry Street & 7th Avenue South, Manhattan, NY
